802.01 APPLICATION OF CHAPTER.
   The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the licensing of all trades,
businesses and professions regulated by these Codified Ordinances, unless
provision is otherwise expressly made for licensing and/or the incidents
thereof in the chapter wherein the trade, business or profession is regulated.
In the event of conflict between the provisions of this chapter and the
provisions of any other chapter of these Codified Ordinances, wherein a trade,
business or profession is regulated, the provisions of the other chapter shall
prevail.
(Ord. 638-95. Passed 4-11-95.)
802.011 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this chapter is to assist the Village with information to
provide more adequate police and fire protection, better efficiency and economy
in furnishing public utility services, more comprehensive and informed planning
and zoning for uses of land and structures within the Village, and to establish
a registry of businesses operating in the Village for the general information
of the public and for promotion of the general health, safety and welfare of
the Village and its residents.
(Ord. 1065-13. Passed 4-1-13; Ord. 1231-19. Passed 12-18-19.)
802.012 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context indicates or requires a different meaning.
   (a)   “Business.” Any trade, occupation, profession, business, franchise,
work, commerce or other activity, owned or operated for profit, by any person
within the Village of Put-in-Bay.
   (b)   “Food court.” An area, such as a section of a building or common area
within a facility, that is contiguous with the counters of multiple food
vendors and provides a common area for self-serve dining.
   (c)   “Person.” Any individual, corporation, limited liability company,
partnership, business trust, estate, trust partnership, trustee, executor,
association or other business entity.
(Ord. 1065-13. Passed 4-1-13; Ord. 1069-13. Passed 5-13-13; Ord. 1231-19.
Passed 12-18-19.)
802.02 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall commence or engage in any business, as herein defined,
within the Village without having first applied for and obtained a business
license from the Fiscal Officer, or other duly authorized issuing authority.
(Ord. 638-95. Passed 4-11-95; Ord. 941-08. Passed 11-10-08; Ord. 1065-13.
Passed 4-1-13.)
802.021 INDEBTEDNESS TO VILLAGE.
   (a)   No license shall be granted to any person if, at the time applying for
such license, such person is indebted to the Village for the present and/or any
preceding licensing year for failure to procure and pay for any license
required by ordinance of the Village.
   (b)   No license necessary or related to the operation of a business shall
be granted to any person if at the time of applying for such license such
person is delinquent on the rolls of the Village Utility Department for any
Village-provided utility services for the present and/or any preceding
licensing year. The Village Fiscal Officer or designee shall prepare a list of
license applicants annually, prior to the time set for annual license issuance
or renewal, and provide the Village Administrator with such list, and the
Village Administrator will return a certified list indicating those applicants
with indebtedness to the Village.
(Ord. 1065-13. Passed 4-1-13; Ord. 1231-19. Passed 12-18-19.)
802.03 LICENSE APPLICATION; LICENSE REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   All applications for business licenses shall be made to the Fiscal
Officer, or his or her designee, in writing upon forms furnished by the Village
and shall contain, at a minimum, the following information:
      (1)   The name and address of the principal place of business;
      (2)   The name and address of the applicant and all individuals having an
ownership interest in the business, their business occupation, place of
business and business address and residence. If the owner is a corporation,
limited liability company, or other nonpersonal business entity, the name and
address of the resident agent(s) or other person representing the entity shall
be provided;
      (3)   The address of all locations within the Village at which the
business intends to operate;
      (4)   Business telephone number and business fax number;
      (5)   A detailed description of the nature of the business and the
services or goods to be provided;
      (6)   The Ohio vendor license number/sales tax number for the business;
      (7)   A Federal identification number for the business;
      (8)   Resort Area Gross Receipts Excise Tax account number for the
business;
      (9)   Proof of State license, if one is necessary for business conducted;
and
      (10)   Such other information concerning the applicant and his or her
trade, business or profession as may be reasonable and proper, having regard to
the nature of the license desired.
   (b)   A separate license is required for each business unit operating in the
Village. A building or property containing one or more business units with each
unit representing itself to the public as a separate business or merchandising
storefront shall be treated as a separate location for reporting and licensing
purposes. The following acts shall create a rebuttable presumption that a
person is engaged in a business unit operation: (i) displaying a sign or
advertisement indicating the conduct of a business or profession at a given
location; (ii) advertising a business or profession in a classified section of
the telephone directory, in the Put- in-Bay Chamber of Commerce business
publication, in newspaper advertisements, on the internet, or any other media;
or (iii) except for a business classified as a food court, where customers are
not free to leave the business unit without being required to pay for
merchandise or services, shall be evidence that such person is holding himself
out to the public as operating a business unit or profession.
   (c)   Each business license must be renewed annually. If there are no
changes to the above-required information and the licensee is in good standing,
renewal of an annual license may be granted upon the initial application filed
with the Village provided that the renewal fee is paid in full.
   (d)   Each business must be conducted at a fixed location on rented, leased
or privately- owned real property. If leased or rented, a copy of the signed
lease or rental agreement must be provided with the license application.
Business must be conducted so as not to impede the flow of vehicular traffic on
public streets and/or so as not to impede the flow of pedestrian traffic on
public sidewalks.
   (e)   At the time of making the application for the required business
license the applicant shall pay to the Village the license fee as established
for each business unit in the Village where the applicant proposes to carry on
business, as defined in subsection (b) hereof.
   (f)   In the event that there is any change or transfer of the ownership of
a business or enterprise, a new application shall be required within sixty days
of the change or transfer of ownership. The new owner shall deposit the fee
required for an original license with the application reflecting said change or
transfer of ownership.
   (g)   It shall be unlawful to knowingly make a false statement or
representation in a license application.
(Ord. 742-99. Passed 6-24-99; Ord. 941-08. Passed 11-10-08; Ord. 1044-12.
Passed 8-3-12; Ord. 1065-13. Passed 4-1-13; Ord. 1069-13. Passed 5-13-13; Ord.
1231-19. Passed 12-18-19.)
802.031 CRITERIA FOR ISSUANCE OF LICENSE.
   (a)   A business license shall be issued to an applicant only upon receipt
of a properly completed application and payment of the applicable license fee,
so long as such business complies with this Title Two, Village ordinances, the
Village Zoning Code and any and all other state, federal and local laws, rules
and/or regulations as are incumbent on said business.
   (b)   Compliance with the following matters as related to the proposed
business location, unless waived by the Village Council upon determination that
such noncompliance is of a minor nature and not adverse to the intent and
purpose of this chapter, shall be required:
      (1)   All Village water and sewer charges serving the business location
are paid in full and current.
      (2)   The business premises is in compliance with all applicable zoning
requirements.
      (3)   The business premises is in compliance with all applicable
requirements of the Village Utility Department.
      (4)   The business premises is in compliance with all other Village
ordinances.
      (5)   The applicant is not delinquent on any taxes due and owing pursuant
to Ohio R.C. 5739.101 and 5739.102.
         (Ord. 1065-13. Passed 4-1-13; Ord. 1231-19. Passed 12-18-19; Ord.1409-
23. Passed 9-12-23.)
802.04 LICENSE ISSUANCE.
   (a)   Upon receipt of a properly completed application for a license,
accompanied by the proper fee, the Fiscal Officer or authorized designee, by
and with the written approval of the Mayor, and so long as approval by Council,
another officer or department is not required, shall forthwith deposit the fee
in the Village Treasury and issue to the applicant a proper license certificate
signed by the Fiscal Officer. If for any reason the license is not issued, this
fee, less ten dollars ($10.00) to cover the expenses of considering such
application, shall be returned to the applicant.
   (b)   The license shall be on a form approved by the Village Council and
signed by the Fiscal Officer. A person licensed under this chapter shall post
such license in a conspicuous place in the place where the business is
conducted.
(Ord. 638-95. Passed 4-11-95; Ord. 941-08. Passed 11-10-08; Ord. 1065-13.
Passed 4-1-13; Ord. 1231-19. Passed 12-18-19.)
802.05 LICENSE DATE, DURATION AND RENEWAL.
   A license shall not be valid beyond the expiration date therein specified
and, unless otherwise provided, shall not extend beyond April 30 of the year
subsequent to issuance. At any time after December 14 of any year, a business
license may be issued for the ensuing calendar year. Annual renewal of a
license granted under this chapter is required on or before the third Monday in
April of a given year. The full annual fee will be required of a licensee
irrespective of the date of issue of the license.
(Ord. 638-95. Passed 4-11-95; Ord. 1065-13. Passed 4-1-13; Ord. 1231-19. Passed
12-18-19.)
802.06 LICENSE TRANSFERABILITY.
   Every license shall be issued to a real party in interest in the enterprise
or business and, unless otherwise provided, no license shall be assigned or
transferred.
(Ord. 638-95. Passed 4-11-95.)
802.07 DISPLAY OF CERTIFICATES.
   Every licensee conducting business at a fixed location shall keep posted in
a prominent place upon the licensed premises, the license certificate. Other
licensees shall carry their license certificates at all times and, whenever
requested by any officer or citizen, shall exhibit the same.
(Ord. 638-95. Passed 4-11-95.)
802.08 GENERAL CONTRACTORS.
   Each general contractor doing work in the Village is responsible for
obtaining one general business license, which will include the general
contractor and any and all subcontractors operating under the auspices of the
general contractor. A contractor must have a business license before a zoning
permit will be issued.
(Ord. 638-95. Passed 4-11-95.)
802.09 BUSINESS LICENSE FEES; GENERAL BUSINESS LICENSE FEES.
   (a)   Any person who engages in the following businesses shall pay a license
fee as set forth in this subsection:
(1)   Bar/food-winery                                           $175.00
(2)   Retail services-gift shop-carry-out                       $175.00
(3)   Hotel-motel-bed and breakfast home/cottage rental short te$175.00
(4)   Fuel sales                                                $175.00
(5)   Repair shops (auto or boat)                               $175.00
(6)   Amusement business                                        $175.00
(7)   Golf cart-scooter-bike rentals and repair                 $175.00
(8)   Taxi-bus-pedicab-tour train                               $175.00
(9)   Ferry service                                             $175.00
(10)   Charter boats                                            $175.00
(11)   Watercraft dockage and marina                            $175.00
(12)   Watercraft rental                                        $175.00
(13)   Purveyors                                                $175.00
(14)   Contractors                                              $175.00
(15)   Food court                                               $175.00
 
   (b)   Each person engaged in a business not listed in paragraph (a) of this
section shall obtain a general business license for each business unit
operated, and shall pay a fee of one hundred seventy-five dollars ($175.00) for
each such license.
   (c)   A general business license shall be issued upon the person's
compliance with the provisions of this Title Two and with Village ordinances,
the Village Zoning Code and any and all other local laws, rules and/or
regulations as are incumbent on said business.
(Ord. 1065-13. Passed 4-1-13; Ord. 1069-13. Passed 5-13-13; Ord. 1437-24.
Passed 3-12-24; Ord. 1438-24. Passed 4-2-24.)
802.10 WHOLESALERS.
   Wholesalers are not required to obtain a business license if they are not
dealing from a fixed location in the Village. Wholesalers must have an
established clientele within the Village before doing business within the
Village.
(Ord. 638-95. Passed 4-11-95.)
802.11 LICENSE REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION.
   (a)   Any business license may be revoked by the Mayor or other chief
administrative officer at any time for conditions or considerations which, had
they existed at the time of issuance, would have been valid grounds for its
denial; for any misrepresentation of a material fact in the application
discovered after issuance of the license or any renewal thereof; for violation
of any provision of this chapter, Title Two, or other applicable law or
ordinance; or upon conviction of a licensee for violating any Federal, State or
municipal law or ordinance involving moral turpitude.
   (b)   The revocation shall become effective upon notice served upon such
licensee or posted upon the premises affected.
   (c)   As a preliminary to revocation, the Mayor or other chief
administrative officer may issue an order suspending the license, which order
shall become effective immediately upon service of written notice to such
licensee. This notice shall specify the reason for suspension and may provide
conditions under which reinstatement of the license may be obtained. Upon
compliance with such conditions within the time specified, the license may be
restored.
(Ord. 638-95. Passed 4-11-95; Ord. 1231-19. Passed 12-18-19.)
802.12 APPEAL AND REVIEW.
   In case any applicant has been denied a license, or if his or her license
has been revoked or suspended, the applicant or licensee, as the case may be,
shall have the right to appeal said denial or revocation to the Village Council
by filing with the Fiscal Officer of the Village, within five days of the
denial or revocation, a written notice of appeal setting forth the specific
grounds for the appeal. The Fiscal Officer, upon receipt of said written notice
of appeal, shall place the same upon the agenda of the next regular Council
meeting, unless said Council meeting is more than three weeks away, in which
case the Fiscal Officer shall proceed to request a special Council meeting if
requested in writing by the appellant, said special meeting to be held within
two weeks of the receipt of appellant’s request, unless otherwise mutually
agreed upon by the Village and appellant. The appellant may appear and be heard
in person or by counsel at said meeting. After said hearing, and provided that
a quorum is present, if a majority of the Councilpersons present vote in favor
of the appellant, then the license shall be issued or fully reinstated as the
case may be. Otherwise, the order appealed from shall become final.
(Ord. 638-95. Passed 4-11-95; Ord. 941-08. Passed 11-10-08; Ord. 1231-19.
Passed 12-18-19.)
802.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any provision of this chapter is
guilty of a minor misdemeanor for a first offense and shall be fined not more
than one hundred dollars ($100.00). For a second or subsequent offense within
one year, such person is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree and shall
be fined not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or imprisoned not
more than thirty days, or both.
CHAPTER 806
Bowling, Billiards and Pool Establishments
806.01   License fees.
806.02   Hours of operation.
806.03   Gambling.
806.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Regulation of bowling alleys - see Ohio R.C. 715.51
   Regulation of pool tables - see Ohio R.C. 715.51
   Licensing of bowling alleys - see Ohio R.C. 715.61
   Licensing in general - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 802
806.01 LICENSE FEES.
   Each proprietor of a billiard or pool table or of a bowling alley, or a
combination of both, shall pay to the Village an annual license fee of fifty
dollars ($50.00) for one such table; fifty dollars ($50.00) for one such alley;
and twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each additional table or alley.
806.02 HOURS OF OPERATION.
   It shall be unlawful to operate any billiard or pool table or bowling alley
between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m.
(1963 Code Sec. 113.01)
806.03 GAMBLING.
   It shall be unlawful to permit betting or gambling in connection with the
use of any billiard or pool table or bowling alley.
(1963 Code Sec. 113.01)
806.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any provision of this chapter is
guilty of a minor misdemeanor for a first offense and shall be fined not more
than one hundred dollars ($100.00). For a second or subsequent offense within
one year, such person is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree and shall
be fined not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or imprisoned not
more than thirty days, or both.
CHAPTER 810
Special Events
810.01   Definitions.
810.02   General authority of Mayor; authority of Village departments.
810.03   Interpretation of this chapter.
810.04   Permit required; application; issuance.
810.05   Indemnification and insurance.
810.06   Permit denial and revocation.
810.07   Appeal of permit denial or revocation.
810.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.48, 715.63, 3765.02
   Power to regulate advertising - see Ohio R.C. 715.65
   Contests or games at county fairs - see Ohio R.C. 1711.09, 1711.11
   State licensing of portable amusement devices - see Ohio R.C. 1711.11(H)
   County license for public shows - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 3765
   Gambling - see GEN. OFF.
Ch. 630
   Littering - see GEN. OFF.
660.03
810.01   DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   “Applicant” means a person who has filed a written application for a
special event permit.
   (b)   “Mayor” means the Mayor of the Village of Put-in-Bay or his/her
designee.
   (c)   “Person” means an individual, firm, partnership, corporation,
association or other legal entity.
   (d)   “Special event” means a temporary event or gathering, using either
private or public property, which involves one or more of the following
activities, except when the activity is for construction or house-moving
purposes only:
      (1)   Closing a public street;
      (2)   Blocking or restriction of public property;
      (3)   Sale of merchandise, food, or beverages on public property or on
private property where otherwise prohibited by law;
      (4)   Erection of a tent on public property;
      (5)   Installation of a stage, band shell, trailer, van, portable
building, grandstand, bleachers, or other similar structure on public property;
      (6)   Placement of portable toilets on public property;
      (7)   Placement of temporary “no parking” signs in a public right-of-way;
      (8)   Circuses, carnivals, sideshows, concerts and similar activities on
public property.
   (e)   “Village" means the Village of Put-in-Bay, Ohio.
(Ord. 1186-18. Passed 4-11-18.)
810.02   GENERAL AUTHORITY OF MAYOR; AUTHORITY OF VILLAGE DEPARTMENTS.
   (a)   The provisions of this chapter shall be administered and enforced by
the Mayor.
   (b)   The Mayor has authority to issue a special event permit that
authorizes one or more of the activities as described in this chapter where the
requirements of this chapter have been met.
   (c)   Each special event date will be considered for approval on a first-
come, first-served basis, based on the date the application was submitted to
the Mayor.
   (d)   Application for a special event permit authorizes appropriate
departments and agencies to review said application.
(Ord. 1186-18. Passed 4-11-18.)
810.03   INTERPRETATION OF THIS CHAPTER.
   The provisions of this chapter are cumulative of all Village ordinances,
tent permits, building permits, electrical permits, food establishment permits,
alcoholic beverage licenses, and all other permits required by ordinance or
other law for specific activities to be conducted in conjunction with or as
part of the special event must be applied for separately in accordance with the
applicable ordinance or other law.
(Ord. 1186-18. Passed 4-11-18.)
810.04   PERMIT REQUIRED; APPLICATION; ISSUANCE.
   (a)   Any person desiring to hold a special event shall apply for a special
event permit by filing with the Mayor a written application on a form provided
for that purpose. Each application must be accompanied by a nonrefundable
application fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). An application must be filed not
less than thirty days before the special event is to begin. The Mayor may waive
the thirty-day filing requirement if the Mayor determines that the application
can be processed in fewer than thirty days, taking into consideration the
number and type of permits required to be issued in conjunction with the
special event permit. The Mayor may also waive the application fee for non-
profit organizations or agencies.
   (b)   An application must contain the following information:
      (1)   Name, address, and telephone number of the applicant responsible
for the conduct of the special event;
      (2)   A description of the special event and requested dates and hours of
operation for the event. Any activity not expressly stated in an approved
application shall be prohibited;
      (3)   The estimated number of persons to participate in the special
event;
      (4)   A sketch showing the area to be used during the special event,
together with proposed structure, tents, fences, barricades, signs, banners,
and restroom facilities;
      (5)   If the special event is to occur on private party, the applicant
shall include in the application a letter of permission signed by the owner of
the property on which the special event is to be held;
      (6)   The time and location of street closings, if any are requested;
      (7)   Details of the sale of merchandise or the sale or serving of food
and/or alcoholic beverages at the special event, designating any street vendors
or peddlers involved;
      (8)   A description of animals to be used in the special event, if any;
      (9)   Details of how the applicant will clean up the area of the special
event after it has ended;
      (10)   Proof that the applicant possesses or is able to obtain all
licenses and permits required by local, state, or federal law for the conduct
of the special event; and
      (11)   Complete Village hold harmless and liability waiver.
   (c)   Upon receipt of the completed application, the Mayor shall forward a
copy of the application to the Police Department, the Fire Department,
Emergency Medical Services (EMS), and the Fiscal Officer. Each department shall
review the application, sign it, and return it, with any comments to the Mayor
within five days of receipt.
   (d)   The department may prescribe licenses and permits required by other
Village ordinances or applicable law, restrictions, regulations, estimated cost
for the Village services, safeguards and other conditions necessary for the
safe and orderly conduct of a special event, to be incorporated into the permit
before issuance.
   (e)   A deposit of one-half of the estimated cost required to be paid the
Village as a result of the special event must be received by the Fiscal Officer
of the Village not fewer than five days before date of the special event as
shown on the special event permit. The remaining fifty percent is due on the
day of the event. If final costs exceed the estimated cost, the difference must
be paid within thirty days after the completion of the event.
   (f)   After reviewing the application and departmental comments and
recommendations, the Mayor shall issue the special event permit or deny the
special event permit.
(Ord. 1186-18. Passed 4-11-18.)
810.05   INDEMNIFICATION AND INSURANCE.
   (a)   An applicant for a special event permit must exhibit proof of a
general liability insurance policy with coverage of not less than one million
dollars ($1,000,000.00). The certificate of general liability insurance must
establish the Village as an additional insured. Additional insurance will be
required for fireworks and pyrotechnics in amounts as determined by the Mayor.
   (b)   Prior to the issuance of a special event permit, the applicant must
sign a hold harmless and liability waiver available in the office of the Mayor.
(Ord. 1186-18. Passed 4-11-18.)
810.06   PERMIT DENIAL AND REVOCATION.
   (a)   The Mayor shall deny a special event permit if:
      (1)   A special event permit has been granted for another special event
at the same place and time;
      (2)   The proposed special event will unreasonably disrupt the orderly
flow of traffic and no reasonable means of rerouting traffic or otherwise
meeting traffic needs is available;
      (3)   The applicant fails to adequately provide for:
         A.   The protection of event participants;
         B.   Crowd security, taking into consideration the size and character
or the event.
      (4)   If the proposed special event will violate a Village ordinance or
other applicable law;
      (5)   The applicant makes a false statement of material fact on the
application;
      (6)   The applicant fails to provide proof that he or she possesses or is
able to obtain a license or permit required by Village ordinance or other
applicable laws for the conduct of all activities included as part of the
special event;
      (7)   The applicant has had a special event permit revoked within the
preceding fourteen months;
      (8)   The applicant has committed, within preceding fourteen months, one
or more violations of a condition or provision of a special event permit; or
the applicant fails to pay any outstanding costs owed to the Village for a past
special event.
   (b)   The Mayor may revoke a special event permit if:
      (1)   The applicant fails to comply with, or the special event is in
violation of, a condition or provision of the special event permit, an
ordinance of the Village, or any other applicable law; or
      (2)   The permit holder makes a false statement of material fact on an
application for a special event permit.
         (Ord. 1186-18. Passed 4-11-18.)
810.07   APPEAL OF PERMIT DENIAL OR REVOCATION.
   (a)   If the Mayor denies an application for a special event permit or
revokes a special event permit, the Mayor shall send the applicant or permit
holder written notice of the denial or revocation and the right to an appeal,
by certified mail, return receipt requested, or the Chief of Police or his
designee may deliver said notice of denial or revocation to the applicant or
permit holder with a signed receipt from the applicant or permit holder.
   (b)   The applicant or permit holder shall have the right to appeal a denial
or revocation of a special event permit to the Village Council by filing with
the Village Administrator, within five days of receipt of the notice of denial
or revocation, a written notice of appeal setting forth the specific grounds
for the appeal.
   (c)   The Village Administrator, upon receipt of said written notice of
appeal, shall place the same upon the agenda of the next regular Council
meeting, unless said Council meeting is more than three weeks away, in which
case the Village Administrator shall proceed to request a special meeting of
Council if requested in writing by the appellant, and said special meeting
shall be held within two weeks.
   (d)   The appellant may appear and be heard in person or by counsel at said
meeting. After such hearing, Council shall decide to grant the appeal, deny the
appeal, or modify the Mayor’s decision by issuing or reinstating the permit
with reasonable conditions. Council’s decision shall be final.
(Ord. 1186-18. Passed 4-11-18.)
810.99   PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any provision of this chapter is
guilty of a minor misdemeanor for a first offense and shall be fined not more
than one hundred dollars ($100.00). For a second or subsequent offense within
one year, such person is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree and shall
be fined not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or imprisoned not
more than thirty days or both.
(Ord. 1186-18. Passed 4-11-18.)
CHAPTER 830
Itinerant Vendors, Peddlers and Solicitors
830.01   Definitions.
830.02   Itinerant vendors; license required; fee.
830.03   Peddlers by hand; license required; fee.
830.04   Peddlers from hand-drawn vehicles; license required; fee.
830.05   Peddlers from other vehicles; license required; fee.
830.06   Solicitors; license required; fee; hours.
830.07   Exceptions.
830.08   Prohibited areas.
830.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Power to inspect food products - see Ohio R.C. 715.46
   Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.61 et seq.
   Home solicitation sales - see Ohio R.C. 1345.21 et seq.
   Charitable solicitations - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 1716
   Frozen desserts - see Ohio R.C. 3717.51 et seq.
   Littering - see Ohio R.C. 3767.20; GEN. OFF.
660.03
   Sales of goods and services within right of way of interstate and other
State highways - see Ohio R.C. 5515.07
   Trespass - see GEN. OFF.
642.12
   Unreasonable noise; obstructing public ways - see GEN. OFF.
648.04(a)(2), (4)
830.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Itinerant vendor" means any person, natural or artificial, who
engages in or conducts a temporary or transient business of selling goods,
wares and merchandise within the Municipality with the intention of continuing
in such business in any one location for a period of not more than four months
and who, for the purpose of carrying on such business, hires, leases or
occupies, in whole or in part, any room, building or structure for the
exhibition and sale of such goods, wares and merchandise. The term does not
apply to hawkers or peddlers, to vendors engaged in the sale of food or food
products for human consumption, to commercial travelers or selling agents when
making sales in the usual course of business, or to salesmen who sell by sample
for future delivery.
   (b)   "Peddler" means any person who travels by any means from place to
place for the purpose of selling goods, wares or merchandise carried by hand,
from hand-drawn vehicles or from other vehicles.
   (c)   "Solicitor" means any person who travels by any means from place to
place, taking or attempting to take orders for the sale of goods to be
delivered in the future or for services to be performed in the future.
(Ord. 638-95. Passed 4-11-95.)
830.02 ITINERANT VENDORS; LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE.
   Every itinerant vendor shall obtain a license before engaging in business
and shall pay a five hundred dollar ($500.00) general business license fee. The
vendor must be in operation a minimum of twelve weeks. This license shall
terminate automatically on the last day for which such sum shall have been
paid.
(Ord. 638-95. Passed 4-11-95.)
830.03 PEDDLERS BY HAND; LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE.
   Every peddler selling goods of any kind carried by hand shall obtain a
license before engaging in business and shall pay a fee therefor of five
hundred dollars ($500.00) per year.
(Ord. 638-95. Passed 4-11-95.)
830.04 PEDDLERS FROM HAND-DRAWN VEHICLES; LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE.
   Every peddler selling fruits, vegetables or goods of any kind from vehicles
drawn by hand shall obtain a license before engaging in business and shall pay
a fee therefor of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per year for each vehicle used
for such purpose.
(Ord. 638-95. Passed 4-11-95.)
830.05 PEDDLERS FROM OTHER VEHICLES; LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE.
   Every peddler selling fruits, vegetables or goods of any kind from vehicles
drawn by means other than hand shall obtain a license before engaging in
business and shall pay a fee therefor of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per
year for each vehicle used for such purpose.
(Ord. 638-95. Passed 4-11-95.)
830.06 SOLICITORS; LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE; HOURS.
   Every solicitor shall obtain a license before engaging in business and shall
pay a fee therefor of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per year and shall limit
his or her soliciting to the hours of 10:00 a.m. to 8:00 p.m.
(Ord. 638-95. Passed 4-11-95.)
830.07 EXCEPTIONS.
   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to an owner of any product of
his or her own raising; to the manufacturer of any articles or products
manufactured by him or her, who, by himself or herself or his or her agent,
peddles or vends any such articles or products; to any person who, by State or
Federal law or constitutional provision, has been exempted from obtaining such
license; or to any sale at wholesale to a retail dealer.
(Ord. 638-95. Passed 4-11-95.)
830.08 PROHIBITED AREAS.
   No itinerant vendor, peddler or solicitor shall engage in any activity
within DeRivera Park or within 500 feet of DeRivera Park, unless authorized
under Chapter 810.
(Ord. 638-95. Passed 4-11-95.)
830.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any provision of this chapter is
guilty of a minor misdemeanor for a first offense and shall be fined not more
than one hundred dollars ($100.00). For a second or subsequent offense within
one year, such person is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree and shall
be fined not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or imprisoned not
more than thirty days, or both.
(Ord. 638-95. Passed 4-11-95.)
CHAPTER 844
Massage Establishments and Adult Cabarets
844.01   Purpose; intent.
844.02   Definitions.
844.03   Application of chapter.
844.04   License required.
844.05   Application for license; renewals.
844.06   Inspections and investigations of applicants.
844.07   Action on application.
844.08   Expiration of license.
844.09   Display of license.
844.10   Revocation of license.
844.11   Inspections of licensed premises; investigations and physical
examinations of licensees.
844.12   General requirements.
844.13   Conduct of employees.
844.14   Records.
844.15   Deposit and use of fees.
844.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Municipal regulation - see Ohio R.C. 715.61
   Sex related offenses - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 2907; GEN. OFF.
Ch. 666
   Massage services in beauty or nail salons - see Ohio R.C. 4713.14 et seq.
   Massage as limited branch of medicine - see Ohio R.C. 4731.15
   Public indecency - see GEN. OFF.
666.06
   Pornography - see GEN. OFF.
666.11 et seq.
   Adult oriented businesses - see P. & Z. 1288.065
844.01 PURPOSE; INTENT.
   This chapter is hereby declared to be an emergency ordinance necessary for
the preservation of the public peace, health, welfare, and safety and for the
further reason that Council finds and determines that regulation of adult
cabarets and massage establishments as defined herein must take effect
immediately to prevent the erosion of the character of the Village of Put-in-
Bay. This chapter shall take effect and be in force immediately upon its
passage and approval by the Mayor.
(Ord. 739-99. Passed 4-22-99.)
844.02 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Adult cabaret" means a nightclub, bar, restaurant, or similar
establishment in which persons appear in a state of nudity and semi-nudity in
the performance of their duties.
   (b)   "License" means a license to operate a massage establishment, or a
license to operate an adult cabaret, issued pursuant to these regulations, or a
license to act as a masseur or masseuse at a massage establishment, issued
pursuant to these regulations.
   (c)   "Massage" means any method of exerting pressure on, stroking,
kneading, rubbing, tapping, pounding, vibrating, or stimulating the external
soft tissue of the body with the hands, or with the aid of any mechanical or
electrical device.
   (d)   "Massage establishment" means any fixed place of business where a
person offers massages, either in exchange for something of value or in
connection with another legitimate service.
   (e)   "Masseur" or "masseuse" means any person who performs massages at a
massage establishment.
   (f)   "Nudity" means the showing of either of the following:
      (1)   The human male or female genitals, pubic area, or buttocks with
less than a fully opaque covering; or
      (2)   The female breast with less than a fully opaque covering on any
part of the nipple.
(Ord. 739-99. Passed 4-22-99.)
844.03 APPLICATION OF CHAPTER.
   (a)   This chapter shall govern massage establishments and adult cabarets
within the Village of Put-in-Bay and the owners, operators, persons in charge,
and employees of such establishments.
   (b)   The regulations regarding massage establishments do not apply to the
practice of any limited branch of medicine or surgery by persons certified to
practice under Ohio R.C. 4731.15 and 4731.16, or the practice of providing
therapeutic massage by a licensed physician, chiropractor, podiatrist, nurse,
or other health care professional licensed, certified, or registered to
practice in the State.
   (c)   This chapter is intended to be fully severable. If any section,
subsection, or clause of this chapter is deemed to be unconstitutional or
otherwise invalid, the validity of the remaining sections, subsections, and
clauses shall not be affected.
(Ord. 739-99. Passed 4-22-99.)
844.04 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (a)   No person shall operate or engage in the operation of a massage
establishment, or allow the operation of a massage establishment, in or on
premises owned or controlled by him or her, without a valid, current license
issued pursuant to this chapter. A separate license is required for each
location at which a massage establishment is opened.
   (b)   No person shall act as a masseur or masseuse for a massage
establishment without a valid, current license issued pursuant to this chapter.
   (c)   No person shall engage in, conduct or carry on an adult cabaret, or
permit an adult cabaret to be engaged in, conducted or carried on, in or on
premises owned or controlled by him or her, without a valid, current license
issued pursuant to this chapter. A separate license is required for each
location in which an adult cabaret is operated.
(Ord. 739-99. Passed 4-22-99.)
844.05 APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; RENEWALS.
   (a)   Application for an original or renewal license shall be in writing
addressed to the Village Administrator.
   (b)   An application for a renewal license shall be filed not later than
thirty days prior to the expiration of the license to be renewed.
   (c)   All applications shall be filed with the Village Administrator.
   (d)   A nonrefundable filing fee shall be filed with an application as
follows:
      (1)   Two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) for an initial license to
operate a massage establishment or adult cabaret;
      (2)   One hundred twenty-five dollars ($125.00) for a renewal license to
operate a massage establishment or adult cabaret;
      (3)   One hundred dollars ($100.00) for an initial licence as a masseur
or masseuse; and
      (4)   Fifty dollars ($50.00) for a renewal license as a masseur or
masseuse.
   (e)   An application for an initial or renewal license to operate a massage
establishment or adult cabaret shall contain the following:
      (1)   The address where the massage establishment or adult cabaret is
operated, or will be operated;
      (2)   The status of the applicant as an individual, partnership or
limited partnership, domestic or foreign corporation, or other entity;
      (3)   The full name, residence address, date of birth, and Social
Security number of the applicant or the person applying on behalf of the
partnership, corporation, or other entity;
      (4)   If the applicant is a partnership or limited partnership, the name
of the partnership; the status of the partnership as general or limited; the
state or other jurisdiction under which it is organized; the address of its
principal office; the address of its principal office in Ohio; its Federal
identification number; the name and address of its statutory agent; the full
name, residence address, date of birth, and Social Security number of each
partner; and the status of each partner as a general or limited partner;
      (5)   If the applicant is a corporation, the name of the corporation; the
state or other jurisdiction under which it is organized; the address of its
principal office; the address of its principal office in Ohio; its Federal
identification number; the name and address of its statutory agent in Ohio; and
the full name, residence address, date of birth, and Social Security number of
each shareholder holding more than two percent of the applicant's stock. If any
shareholder is a corporation or a general or limited partnership, the same
information shall be included for such shareholder as is required for an
applicant that is a corporation or general or limited partnership;
      (6)   The full name, residence address, date of birth, and Social
Security number of each person employed by the massage establishment or whose
employment is contemplated by the establishment, and the capacity in which such
person is or is to be employed;
      (7)   A statement that the applicant, and, to the applicant's knowledge,
the persons named in the application, have never been convicted of or pleaded
guilty to any offense other than a misdemeanor traffic offense, or a statement
listing the offenses other than misdemeanor traffic offenses of which the
applicant or any person named in the application has been convicted, including
the offense, date of conviction, and the name and location of the court;
      (8)   A statement by the applicant for a license to operate an adult
cabaret that the Ohio Liquor Control Commission has never, pursuant to Ohio
R.C. 4301.25, revoked a permit held by the applicant or any person or entity
named in the application;
      (9)   Authorization for an investigation into the background, including
any criminal record, of the applicant and any person or entity named in the
application, including authorization to conduct subsequent investigations to
supplement or update information;
      (10)   The applicant's agreement to abide by these regulations and the
laws of Ohio, and any amendments, additions, or reenactments thereof; and
      (11)   Proof that the applicant is in compliance with all applicable
zoning ordinances and restrictions.
   (f)   An application for a license or renewal license as a masseur or
masseuse shall contain the following:
      (1)   The full name, residence address, date of birth, and Social
Security number of the applicant;
      (2)   A statement of the applicant's training, experience, and other
qualifications as a masseur or masseuse;
      (3)   The written report of a physical examination of the applicant by a
physician licensed to practice in Ohio, stating the date of the examination and
certifying that as of that date the applicant is free from communicable
diseases. The date of the physical examination shall be not more than thirty
days prior to the date of filing the application;
      (4)   Two clear, color photographs of the applicant, taken not more than
thirty days prior to the date of filing the application;
      (5)   Authorization of an investigation into the background and any
criminal record of the applicant, including authorization for subsequent
investigations to supplement or update the information; and
      (6)   The applicant's agreement to abide by these regulations and the
laws of Ohio, and any amendments, additions, or reenactments thereof.
(Ord. 739-99. Passed 4-22-99; Ord. 941-08. Passed 11-10-08.)
844.06 INSPECTIONS AND INVESTIGATIONS OF APPLICANTS.
   (a)   Upon receipt of an application for a license or a renewal license to
operate a massage establishment or adult cabaret, the Village Administrator
shall notify the State or local authorities designated by the Village Council
to conduct health and safety inspections of the specified premises, and to
determine compliance or noncompliance with applicable health and safety codes.
Written reports of such inspections shall be prepared by the inspectors and
filed with the Village Administrator, and shall become part of the application
for a license.
   (b)   Upon receipt of an application for a license or a renewal license to
operate a massage establishment or adult cabaret, or an application for a
license or renewal license as a masseur or masseuse, the Village Administrator
shall refer the applicant to the Village Police Department to be fingerprinted,
and shall notify the Police Chief to conduct an investigation into the
background of the applicant and other persons or entities named in the
application. A written report of the results of the investigation shall be
prepared by the investigating officer or agency and filed with the Village
Administrator and shall become part of the application for such license.
(Ord. 739-99. Passed 4-22-99; Ord. 941-08. Passed 11-10-08.)
844.07 ACTION ON APPLICATION.
   (a)   The Village Council shall act on an application within thirty days
after the filing of the reports required by Section
844.06. If the Village Council finds that additional information, inspections
or investigations are reasonably necessary to evaluate the application
properly, it may order the applicant to file supplemental information or order
supplemental inspections and investigations and postpone action on the
application pending receipt of the supplemental information or reports.
   (b)   The application will be denied if:
      (1)   The application is incomplete, contains any false information, or
fails to comply with these regulations;
      (2)   The applicant is a limited partnership, corporation, or other
entity that is not in good standing in the jurisdiction where organized or is
not authorized to do business in Ohio;
      (3)   The operation of a massage establishment or adult cabaret at the
specified location would violate existing zoning restrictions;
      (4)   The report of the health and safety inspections conducted pursuant
to Section
844.06(a) reveals any unsanitary, unsafe, or hazardous condition on the
premises subject to the license or renewal license or any violation of
applicable health or safety codes;
      (5)   The applicant for a license to operate a massage establishment or
adult cabaret has failed to cooperate with any required health or safety
inspection or background investigation;
      (6)   The applicant for a license or renewal license as a masseur or
masseuse has failed to cooperate with any required background investigation;
      (7)   The report of the physical examination filed with the application
for a license or renewal license as a masseur or masseuse reveals that the
applicant suffers from a communicable disease;
      (8)   The applicant or any person named in the license or renewal license
to operate a massage establishment or adult cabaret is under age eighteen;
      (9)   The applicant for a license or renewal license as a masseur or
masseuse is under age twenty-one;
      (10)   The applicant or any person named in the application for an
initial or renewal license to operate a massage establishment or adult cabaret,
or the applicant for a license or renewal license as a masseur or masseuse,
within the past five years has been convicted of or pleaded guilty to an
offense under Ohio R.C. Chapter 2907 or a substantially equivalent offense
under any municipal or village ordinance in Ohio, or under the laws of another
state or territory or of the United States, or under a municipal or village
ordinance in any such jurisdiction;
      (11)   Any masseur or masseuse employed by the massage establishment for
which a renewal license is sought, or the applicant for a license or renewal
license as a masseur or masseuse, has been convicted of or pleaded guilty to a
violation of Ohio R.C. 503.42;
      (12)   The applicant or any person named in the application for an
initial or renewal license to operate an adult cabaret, or any person named in
the application for an adult cabaret, or any person employed at the adult
cabaret, has been convicted of or pleaded guilty to a violation of Ohio R.C.
503.53(C);
      (13)   The applicant is not in compliance will all applicable zoning
ordinances; or
      (14)   The applicant has violated these regulations, or aided and abetted
any violation of these regulations.
   (c)   A license or renewal license to operate a massage establishment or
adult cabaret shall contain the address of the licensed premises, the name and
address of the license holder, and the date of issuance and the date of
expiration of the license.
   (d)   A license or renewal license as a masseur or masseuse shall contain
the name, address, date of birth, physical description, and a clear, color
photograph of the licensee, and the date of issuance and the date of expiration
of the license.
(Ord. 739-99. Passed 4-22-99.)
844.08 EXPIRATION OF LICENSE.
   A license to operate a massage establishment or adult cabaret, or a license
as a masseur or masseuse, is valid for one year, and expires on the anniversary
of the date of issuance, unless sooner revoked as provided in these
regulations.
(Ord. 739-99. Passed 4-22-99.)
844.09 DISPLAY OF LICENSE.
   The license to operate a massage establishment or adult cabaret shall be
prominently displayed in an area of the premises open to the public. The
license of a masseur or masseuse shall be prominently displayed in the area
where the licensee provides massages.
(Ord. 739-99. Passed 4-22-99.)
844.10 REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   The Mayor may at any time revoke a license issued pursuant to this chapter,
on any of the same grounds listed in Section
844.07(b) for denial of the license, including any such ground arising or
discovered after issuance of a license. The Village Administrator shall
promptly notify the licensee in writing of the order of revocation.
(Ord. 739-99. Passed 4-22-99; Ord. 941-08. Passed 11-10-08.)
844.11 INSPECTIONS OF LICENSED PREMISES; INVESTIGATIONS AND PHYSICAL
EXAMINATIONS OF LICENSEES.
   (a)   Health and safety inspections of licensed premises may be conducted at
intervals of one month after issuance or renewal of a license, to ensure
continued compliance with health and safety codes. In addition, the Village
Council may order health and safety inspections at any time that there is
reasonable cause to believe that an unsanitary, unsafe, or hazardous condition
exists on the premises. The Village Administrator shall notify the appropriate
authorities or agencies to make such inspections at the designated times.
Written reports of inspections shall be filed with the Village Administrator.
   (b)   Village personnel or agents may at all reasonable times inspect
licensed premises to ensure continued compliance with the laws of Ohio and this
chapter.
   (c)   At any time there is reasonable cause to do so, the Village Council
may order a background investigation, including the criminal record, if any, of
any licensee, person named in a license application, or employee of a licensee.
Written reports of such investigations shall be filed with the Village
Administrator.
   (d)   Every month after issuance of a license as a masseur or masseuse, the
licensee shall undergo a physical examination by a physician licensed to
practice in Ohio to determine that the licensee remains free of communicable
diseases. The Village Council may also order a licensee to undergo a physical
examination at any time there is reasonable cause to believe the licensee has a
communicable disease. The Village Administrator shall notify the licensee when
an examination is ordered, but no notice is required for the periodic monthly
exam. The licensee is responsible for obtaining such examination. The
physician's report shall be filed with the Village Administrator.
(Ord. 739-99. Passed 4-22-99; Ord, 941-08. Passed 11-10-08.)
844.12 GENERAL REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   Massage establishments shall be closed and shall not operate between
the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 1:00 p.m. of the following day. An adult cabaret
shall close no later than 12:00 midnight or no later than the closing time
required under its license to sell alcoholic beverages, whichever is later;
shall reopen no earlier than 6:00 p.m.; and shall not operate between those
hours.
   (b)   All parts of the establishment shall at all times be maintained in a
neat, clean, sanitary, and safe condition.
   (c)   The owner, operator, or person in charge of the establishment shall
allow State or local authorities, including law enforcement officers, access to
any and all parts of the premises for the purpose of making health or safety
inspections pursuant to these regulations, and shall cooperate in any
background investigations.
   (d)   No person under age eighteen shall be employed by or in a massage
establishment or adult cabaret in any capacity, whether full-time or part-time,
and with or without remuneration or compensation in any form.
   (e)   No massage establishment shall employ a masseur or masseuse who does
not hold a valid, current license issued pursuant to this chapter.
   (f)   No adult cabaret shall be established or operated within 500 feet of
the boundaries of any parcel of real estate having situated on it a school,
church, library, public playground, or park.
   (g)   A licensee shall file a list of employees with the Village
Administrator, and shall file an amended list at any time there is a change in
personnel. The list shall state the name, address, date of birth, and position
of each employee.
   (h)   The owner, operator, or person in charge of a massage establishment or
adult cabaret shall exercise adequate supervision to insure that the employees
comply at all times with this chapter and the laws of the State of Ohio.
   (i)   Any employee of an adult cabaret appearing on the premises in a state
of nudity or semi-nudity must be on a stage that is:
      (1)   At least twenty-four inches above floor level; and
      (2)   Removed at least six feet from the nearest other employee or
customer.
(Ord. 739-99. Passed 4-22-99; Ord. 941-08. Passed 11-10-08.)
844.13 CONDUCT OF EMPLOYEES.
   (a)   A person under the age of eighteen shall not accept or continue
employment by or in a massage establishment or adult cabaret, in any capacity,
whether full-time or part-time, and with or without remuneration or
compensation of any kind.
   (b)   No person shall accept or continue employment by any massage
establishment or adult cabaret that does not have a valid current license
issued pursuant to this chapter.
   (c)   Any masseur or masseuse, and any employee of an adult cabaret, shall
cooperate with any background investigation under this chapter.
   (d)   A masseur or masseuse shall obtain a physical examination whenever
required to do so under these regulations.
   (e)   No employee of a massage establishment, in the performance of his or
her duties, shall do any of the following:
      (1)   Knowingly touch or fondle, or offer or agree to touch or fondle,
the genitalia, pubic area, rectal area, or perineum of any person, or the
breast of any female person, whether touching or fondling is with part of the
actor's body or with a mechanical or electrical apparatus or appliance;
      (2)   Knowingly engage in, or offer or agree to engage in, sexual conduct
or sexual contact as defined in Ohio R.C. 2907.01, whether such sexual conduct
or sexual contact is with part of the actor's body or with a mechanical or
electrical apparatus or appliance;
      (3)   Commit, or offer or agree to commit, any offense under Ohio R.C.
Chapter 2907;
      (4)   When providing a massage, knowingly allow the pubic or genital area
or buttocks of the client, or the breasts of a female client, to be uncovered;
      (5)   Go unclothed, or wear clothing that is transparent or translucent,
or wear clothing in such a way as to reveal or display the pubic or genital
area or buttocks or, if the person is a female, the breast; or
      (6)   Wear unclean clothing, or fail to wash his or her hands or bathe
when reasonably necessary, or otherwise fail to observe reasonable standards of
personal cleanliness and hygiene.
   (f)   No employee of an adult cabaret, in the performance of his or her
duties, shall do any of the following:
      (1)   Place his or her hand upon, touch with any part of his or her body,
fondle in any manner, or massage, the genitals, pubic area, or buttocks of any
other person or the breasts of any female or, if the employee is female, of any
other female;
      (2)   Perform or offer or agree to perform any act that would require the
touching of the genitals, pubic area, or buttocks of any other person or the
breasts of any female, or, if the employee is female, the breasts of another
female;
      (3)   Uncover the genitals, pubic area, or buttocks of any other person
or the breasts of any female or, if the employee is a female, of any other
female; or
      (4)   While in a state of nudity or semi-nudity, knowingly or
intentionally initiate any physical contact with a customer of such adult
cabaret, or permit a customer of such adult cabaret to have any physical
contact with such employee. No customer of an adult cabaret shall knowingly or
intentionally initiate any physical contact with an employee of an adult
cabaret while such employee is in a state of nudity or semi-nudity or permit an
employee of an adult cabaret, while such employee is in a state of nudity or
semi-nudity, to have any physical contact with such customer. This subsection
shall not prohibit an employee or a customer from taking such action as is
necessary to repel physical contact, nor shall this subsection prohibit an
employee or customer from initiating or permitting such contact as necessary to
protect the health or safety of any person.
(Ord. 739-99. Passed 4-22-99.)
844.14 RECORDS.
   The Village Administrator shall keep a complete record of all documents and
proceedings under these regulations, including, without limitation,
applications, reports, copies of permits and licenses issued, notices,
correspondence, licensee employee lists, Council proceedings, resolutions and
orders, and petitions. All documents shall be endorsed by the Village
Administrator with the date of filing.
(Ord. 739-99. Passed 4-22-99; Ord. 941-08. Passed 11-10-08.)
844.15 DEPOSIT AND USE OF FEES.
   Fees collected by the Village for licenses under this chapter shall be
deposited into the Village General Fund, and first applied to the cost of
administering and enforcing these regulations.
(Ord. 739-99. Passed 4-22-99.)
844.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any provision of this chapter is
guilty of a minor misdemeanor for a first offense and shall be fined not more
than one hundred dollars ($100.00). For a second or subsequent offense within
one year, such person is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree and shall
be fined not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or imprisoned not
more than thirty days, or both.
CHAPTER 850
Private/Special Police and Private Detectives
850.01   Private police defined.
850.02   License required; fee.
850.03   Reports to Chief of Police.
850.04   Misconduct.
850.05   Violations.
850.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.61
   Private investigators and security services - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4749
   Police Department - see ADM.
Ch. 244
   Impersonating an officer - see GEN. OFF.
606.25,
642.20
850.01 PRIVATE POLICE DEFINED.
   As used in this chapter, "private policeman" means any person who is not
commissioned by a municipality as a police officer and who belongs to a
particular agency that is not affiliated with the Municipality, the County
Sheriff or the State of Ohio. This definition shall include "special policeman"
and "private detective" as well.
(Ord. 429. Passed 5-8-80.)
850.02 LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE.
   (a)   No person or organization shall engage in any form of private police
work or private security work or act as a night watchman without first having
applied for and obtained a license therefor from the Clerk-Treasurer or other
person having authority to issue said license.
(Ord. 429. Passed 5-8-80.)
   (b)   The annual license fee for such a license shall be fifty dollars
($50.00) per year. Said year shall begin May 1 and shall end April 30 of each
year.
850.03 REPORTS TO CHIEF OF POLICE.
   (a)   Every private/special police agency or private detective agency shall
submit a twice yearly report not later than June 7 and October 7 of each year
to the Chief of Police. Said report shall contain the name or identity of each
person, including each person's full name, address, date of birth and Social
Security number. Said report shall contain the dates and times as well as the
place the person worked and shall include a list of all employees discharged
the past six months.
   (b)   Any police action taken by any employee of such agency, other than
regular patrol duty, must be reported to the Chief of Police immediately after
the tour of duty is complete.
   (c)   Any personal property found, turned in or recovered by any private/
special policeman or private detective shall be reported immediately to the
Chief of Police or a command officer and turned in, along with a short report
as to how the individual came in contact with such object.
(Ord. 429. Passed 5-8-80.)
850.04 MISCONDUCT.
   (a)   Any misconduct of any private/special policeman or private detective
shall be reported to the Chief of Police immediately.
   (b)   In the event that misconduct is known to the person operating a
private/special police agency or private detective agency, the person in charge
of such agency must submit a report immediately to the Chief of Police, and, if
necessary, appear and bring action against the private/special policeman or
private detective conducting himself or herself improperly.
   (c)   If a private/special policeman or private detective conducts himself
or herself improperly and his or her conduct is known to a regular police
officer, the regular police officer shall call his or her commanding officer,
who shall take the necessary action and submit a report which shall be
forwarded to the Chief of Police and then, in turn, to the person in charge of
the agency operation.
(Ord. 429. Passed 5-8-80.)
850.05 VIOLATIONS.
   (a)   Failure to comply with any requirement as to submission of any
information, as provided for in this chapter, shall be deemed a violation of
this chapter and considered as just cause to revoke the license or permission
to operate within this jurisdiction for the person or agency involved.
   (b)   A violation of this chapter shall constitute grounds for revocation of
a permit to operate or for arrest of the person in violation.
(Ord. 429. Passed 5-8-80.)
850.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any provision of this chapter is
guilty of a minor misdemeanor for a first offense and shall be fined not more
than one hundred dollars ($100.00). For a second or subsequent offense within
one year, such person is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree and shall
be fined not more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or imprisoned not
more than thirty days, or both.
CHAPTER 858
Rental Vehicles

carts.
858.03   Licensing of businesses engaged in rentals.
858.04   Powers of Council.

858.06   Limitation on golf cart rentals.
 
858.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES

   Bus routes - see TRAF.
